quotes.topic_title: Cold open: Mihika’s reputation and ambition
quotes.text: My take is that your scope is the world. Nothing should ever perceive as being out of bounds.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A mindset framework for setting ambition and avoiding self-imposed constraints when defining product scope.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: Mihika’s reputation and ambition
quotes.text: We lean heavily into designing and prototyping even before a project gets a green light. If you and your team do your job correctly, what does the world look like?
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A practical methodology: use prototyping early to make the end-state tangible and align the team on outcomes before formal approval.

quotes.topic_title: Cold open: Mihika’s reputation and ambition
quotes.text: We have this concept called Maker Week, which is our internal hackathon, giving people the breathing space to see ahead into the horizon and be wildly ambitious.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A concrete cultural mechanism for fostering entrepreneurship by creating dedicated time and space for ambitious exploration.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we drill into many of the skills that Mahika has cultivated that have contributed to her success, including how to develop a compelling vision, get buy-in for your ideas, how to develop conviction, empathy, the importance of culture, and how to create a culture on your team and within the company, and also how to deal with the constant change that happens within successful organizations.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical checklist of core skills to build and lead effectively inside fast-changing organizations.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We also spent a bunch of time on how to effectively bring new ideas in your company from zero to one to launch, including getting to a bunch of the stories behind some of Figma's most successful products and features, and how many of them began at hackathons and Maker Weeks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a repeatable 0→1 pathway and a concrete mechanism (hackathons/Maker Weeks) for generating successful product bets.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: On this podcast, I bring on a lot of amazing senior product leaders, but there's so much we can learn from stellar on-the-ground product managers like Mahika.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive reminder that tactical, in-the-trenches PM experience can be as instructive as senior leadership perspectives.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Paragon enables your engineering team to ship integrations seven times faster than building in-house by removing the complexities around authentication, messy third-party APIs, and debugging integration errors.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific performance claim and causal levers that teams can evaluate when deciding whether to build vs. buy integrations.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Paragon enables your engineering team to ship integrations seven times faster than building in-house by removing the complexities around authentication, messy third-party APIs, and debugging integration errors.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete productivity claim plus a clear breakdown of the main sources of integration complexity teams can offload.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Engineering teams at companies like Copy.ai, Cinch, TLDB, and over 100 other SaaS companies are using Paragon so they can focus their efforts on core product features, not integrations.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Memorable prioritization principle—protect core product work by avoiding long-tail integration maintenance—backed by adoption examples.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I've introduced over 30 companies to their next hire and helped build a candidate pipeline for tons more.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Specific track record data point that highlights the value of proactive pipeline-building versus reactive hiring.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I'm beta testing a bespoke headhunting style service and I'm opening up a handful of slots. We work with a select group of companies each month.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Operational model insight: a high-touch, capacity-limited approach to recruiting that emphasizes focus and quality over volume.

quotes.topic_title: Framing: strengths-based PMing and growth mindset
quotes.text: One thing to call out is that I think when I think about my own PM style, it's definitely not a tick-all-the-boxes style. There are plenty of things that I'm very bad at that PMs are traditionally supposed to be great at, so happy to chat about what makes sense.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A contrarian take that you don’t need to fit the “complete PM” mold to be effective—lean into what works for you.

quotes.topic_title: Framing: strengths-based PMing and growth mindset
quotes.text: The way I see this is a reverse performance review. Here's all the things you're amazing at, let's just go spend all our time on that.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A strengths-based framing for development: invest disproportionately in what you already do exceptionally well.

quotes.topic_title: Framing: strengths-based PMing and growth mindset
quotes.text: It's important to have two things. One is of course lean into your strengths.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Direct, actionable advice to prioritize and amplify your comparative advantages in a generalist role.

quotes.topic_title: Framing: strengths-based PMing and growth mindset
quotes.text: So, for me personally, it was I have always been a very left brain, right brain kind of a person. I majored in CS and minored in visual arts. And when I worked as a software engineer, I really missed the design side, and when I worked as a designer, I missed the technical. And moving into product was a really great way to kind of straddle both and have more touch points across the product development cycle.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A concrete example of using your “spikes” (hybrid strengths) to choose a role and increase leverage across the product lifecycle.

quotes.topic_title: Framing: strengths-based PMing and growth mindset
quotes.text: But for the other things, it's also of course important to have a growth mindset and to constantly be conquering what comes next.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Balances strengths-based PMing with continuous improvement so weaknesses don’t become blockers over time.

quotes.topic_title: Crafting vision: anchor through chaos
quotes.text: Because the reality of the product development cycle is that it's so messy, it's so chaotic. You're going to have extreme highs and extreme lows. You're going to march in a certain direction only to hear from your users that it might just be the wrong direction, and totally pivot. And in order to ensure that moments that are not discouraging, but rather, learning opportunities for your team team, it's so important to be anchored on that singular vision because then any step along the way feels like forward progress.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A practical mental model for using vision as an emotional and strategic anchor through pivots and setbacks so teams interpret turbulence as progress.

quotes.topic_title: Crafting vision: anchor through chaos
quotes.text: You have to be fundamentally inseparable from your users, and also, fundamentally inseparable from your team.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A crisp principle for vision-building: it’s not a solo exercise, it requires deep coupling to both user reality and internal execution partners.

quotes.topic_title: Crafting vision: anchor through chaos
quotes.text: You want to always ensure that there are research insights that help you feel what a user is feeling. You want to ensure that there are beautiful designs and prototypes that help communicate what this future world looks like, and you also want to root it in engineering and feasibility.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A cross-functional checklist for crafting vision that is simultaneously empathetic, tangible, and buildable.

quotes.topic_title: Crafting vision: anchor through chaos
quotes.text: And I think that to the extent that you can have this cross-pollination of ideas and people working together, that leads to a really strong vision.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A methodology claim that challenges linear “handoff” visioning in favor of concurrent, collaborative iteration across functions.

quotes.topic_title: Crafting vision: anchor through chaos
quotes.text: But rather how can you bring all of those things together and how can a vision pitch effectively be pain point, solution, proof point, pain point solution proof point?
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A repeatable internal pitch structure that interleaves evidence with narrative to make vision more persuasive.

quotes.topic_title: FigJam vision example: democratizing meetings
quotes.text: And there was this gap between the way that we were using FigJam as a company and the way that the rest of the world was using it, but brainstorms were working.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Highlights a practical product-discovery method: look for mismatches between power-user behavior and mainstream usage, then anchor on what already works.

quotes.topic_title: FigJam vision example: democratizing meetings
quotes.text: And what it comes down to is brainstorms are this incredibly democratizing process. It's this process where ideas can come from anywhere, where it's not the loudest or the most important person in the room who's doing the talking, but it's everyone altogether.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Defines the core mechanism behind a successful use case (brainstorming) in a way teams can generalize into a product vision.

quotes.topic_title: FigJam vision example: democratizing meetings
quotes.text: And so, what we fundamentally started marching towards was how can we create this world where the generative nature of a brainstorm is basically the norm in other kinds of meetings.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A clear vision-expansion move: take a proven interaction pattern and deliberately apply it across adjacent workflows.

quotes.topic_title: FigJam vision example: democratizing meetings
quotes.text: And so how can we ensure that those kind of rituals are in our templates and that we're teaching people how to take any meeting and make it more democratic?
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Actionable go-to-market/product tactic: encode desired behaviors into templates and education, not just features.

quotes.topic_title: FigJam vision example: democratizing meetings
quotes.text: So, then we started launching features like music, like voting, that really help you get into flow when you're in that pile together.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Concrete examples of translating an abstract vision (democratic, participatory meetings) into specific feature bets.

quotes.topic_title: How to deliver vision: one shared artifact
quotes.text: Definitely. I think that when you're actually presenting a vision, one of the most important things is that there is a single artifact that the team is creating together.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A practical methodology for vision delivery: align the team around one shared output instead of fragmented documents.

quotes.topic_title: How to deliver vision: one shared artifact
quotes.text: And what you actually want is for everyone to feel incredible ownership and incredible passion about this combined deliverable, so that it's a unified team who believes a singular set of insights.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Explains the mechanism of the “single artifact” approach—shared ownership creates unified belief and alignment.

quotes.topic_title: How to deliver vision: one shared artifact
quotes.text: Yeah, exactly. So, we often make our decks in Figma, and I think that we lean heavily into designing and prototyping even before a project gets a green light.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A concrete example of the shared artifact (a Figma deck) and a tactic (prototype before approval) teams can replicate.

quotes.topic_title: How to deliver vision: one shared artifact
quotes.text: Versus Figma is very much a see to believe and see to feel that emotional pull towards this is something worth investing in.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for building conviction: make the future tangible enough that people can emotionally “feel” it.

quotes.topic_title: Prototyping without skills: AI and asking for help
quotes.text: I think something that's interesting about the current AI revolution is that it's very much lowering the floor to starting out and to building something.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A practical mental model for PMs: AI reduces the minimum skill/resources needed to prototype and start building.

quotes.topic_title: Prototyping without skills: AI and asking for help
quotes.text: I think, conversely at Figma we kind of think about if we're doing our job, maybe in the future people will think about Figma as their designer co-founder, where you can go in and use it to start bringing things into existence.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A memorable framing for using tools as “co-founders” to compensate for missing design/engineering capabilities.

quotes.topic_title: Prototyping without skills: AI and asking for help
quotes.text: I think the second piece is just go around and ask people.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Direct, actionable advice: proactively recruit collaborators instead of waiting for formal resourcing.

quotes.topic_title: Prototyping without skills: AI and asking for help
quotes.text: And I think that most people think that, "Oh, hackathons are only a time for engineers to build." And I think that that's one of the biggest mistakes ever.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A contrarian take that reframes hackathons as an opportunity for anyone (including PMs) to drive ideas forward.

quotes.topic_title: Prototyping without skills: AI and asking for help
quotes.text: Literally, what I did was walk around the New York office asking every single person, "Will you work on this thing with me?" And eventually, someone says yes, and then you can use that to build momentum, grow the team, and build something great.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A concrete, repeatable tactic for assembling a team: ask broadly until you get a “yes,” then use it to create momentum.

quotes.topic_title: Building conviction fast: intuition and two-way doors
quotes.text: I think that one of the most important things for a PM to create for their team is momentum. You have to constantly be creating forward progress, probably towards that vision that we were just talking about.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Frames conviction as a practical mechanism for generating momentum and forward progress toward a vision.

quotes.topic_title: Building conviction fast: intuition and two-way doors
quotes.text: But I'm a huge proponent of Jeff Bezos's one-way doors, two-way doors framework. And I think that especially in a software company, most things are two-way doors. You can come back.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Encourages faster decision-making by treating most software decisions as reversible “two-way doors.”

quotes.topic_title: Building conviction fast: intuition and two-way doors
quotes.text: And so, it's so important to have an opinion and use that opinion to anchor people around and have people react to.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Offers a concrete tactic: share a point of view early to create alignment and elicit useful reactions.

quotes.topic_title: Building conviction fast: intuition and two-way doors
quotes.text: And I think my take is that putting out an idea, even if it's totally wrong, is a much better catalyst for getting to a good solution because people are much more likely to react to an idea than to nothing.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance that starting with a potentially-wrong hypothesis accelerates learning and convergence.

quotes.topic_title: Building conviction fast: intuition and two-way doors
quotes.text: You need to be so sort of strong opinions weekly held.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Captures the balance between decisive leadership and adaptability when new evidence emerges.

quotes.topic_title: Directness with trust: calibrating confidence and feedback
quotes.text: So now, I'll do this thing where I'll be like, "Oh, I think we should do this, but I feel like medium confidence on it." So if you feel stronger like, "I defer to you," and always being very, very, very explicit about like, "I feel really strongly about this," or, "This is my hypothesis," or, "I do not have an opinion here. I defer to you."
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A practical framework for calibrating conviction so strong opinions don’t silence the room and others know when to push back.

quotes.topic_title: Directness with trust: calibrating confidence and feedback
quotes.text: Because I think sometimes what can happen is really strongly minded PMs can go into a conversation and can be like, "Oh, I think we should do X," even though they actually feel medium confidence about X. And then the rest of the room is like, "Oh, my God. That PM feels so strongly about doing X that I'm not going to say anything because they clearly have so much conviction in X."
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A counterintuitive failure mode: projecting certainty can reduce team voice even when you’re not actually certain.

quotes.topic_title: Directness with trust: calibrating confidence and feedback
quotes.text: So I think that directness only works if it's two-way.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A simple rule that prevents “directness” from turning into one-way criticism and eroding trust.

quotes.topic_title: Directness with trust: calibrating confidence and feedback
quotes.text: And the way that I try and create this culture of constant direct communication, constant feedback is if you have feedback to give someone else, I think you can start by asking, "Hey, do you have feedback from me?"
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: An actionable tactic to make feedback safer and more balanced by taking feedback first.

quotes.topic_title: Directness with trust: calibrating confidence and feedback
quotes.text: And then feedback in my opinion is something that you should always act on.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A high-leverage norm: acting quickly on feedback increases credibility and encourages others to share more.

quotes.topic_title: Hype as a PM responsibility: internal momentum moments
quotes.text: When you are spearheading an idea or a product, it's really on you to have a pulse on how everyone else is feeling about that product.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Frames “hype” as a PM-owned responsibility: actively monitoring org sentiment to keep a product moving.

quotes.topic_title: Hype as a PM responsibility: internal momentum moments
quotes.text: On the flip side, if you yourself are pushing a zero to one idea from the bottoms up, the onus is even more on you to make sure that that project and that product is constantly propped up and that people are excited about it to make it out the door.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for bottom-up 0→1 bets: you must continually create internal momentum or the work won’t ship.

quotes.topic_title: Hype as a PM responsibility: internal momentum moments
quotes.text: Yeah, it was so important to me that this product got visibility in this forum because this was the first company-wide forum of the year where we were declaring priorities for the year.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Concrete tactic: use high-leverage company moments (like the first all-hands of the year) to lock in priority and attention.

quotes.topic_title: Hype as a PM responsibility: internal momentum moments
quotes.text: And I think what ended up happening is something like that, a demo that wasn't meant to be a demo or that people weren't expecting does so much in terms of driving that sense of hype and helping people see what you yourself see in the future.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Counterintuitive playbook: an unexpected demo can create disproportionate hype and alignment around a future vision.

quotes.topic_title: Hype as a PM responsibility: internal momentum moments
quotes.text: And what's really interesting is I think that hype is something that... You can't really create hype for something you don't believe in my opinion. The only way to create hype is to get people to see what you see.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Memorable mental model: hype isn’t manufactured; it’s created by transferring conviction and vision to others.

quotes.topic_title: External hype and delight: FigJam birthday launch
quotes.text: In my mind, there is internal hype, which is how do you get buy-in and everyone inside of the company to be fanging their fist on the table for a product to get built, but there's also external hype, which is like how do you get your users hyped about your product?
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Introduces a practical two-part framework for generating momentum: internal buy-in vs. external user excitement.

quotes.topic_title: External hype and delight: FigJam birthday launch
quotes.text: But we were really thinking like, "Okay, FigJam is awesome, but FigJam isn't just any product. Figjam has a personality. FigJam is cheeky. FigJam is fun. FigJam has this cute skeuomorphism going on where you feel like it's your friend. And so okay, how would you celebrate that moment for a friend?" You wouldn't really have an anniversary party. You would throw it a full on birthday party.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Shows how to translate product brand/personality into a launch concept that feels emotionally resonant rather than corporate.

quotes.topic_title: External hype and delight: FigJam birthday launch
quotes.text: And what we did was we Easter egged them through the product and each sort of product that we were releasing inside of FigJam was hidden under this little birthday present. And throughout the day, we sent all of our users on an Easter egg hunt of presents inside of FigJam.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A concrete tactic for creating delight and engagement: ship features as an in-product scavenger hunt.

quotes.topic_title: External hype and delight: FigJam birthday launch
quotes.text: I think that hype as well is really tied to emotion. So to the extent that a person using a product can feel like, "Oh, this thing that is built in the product was built for me not to advance the company's goals or anything like that, but to make me feel special, to make me feel happy."
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A repeatable principle for driving hype: make users feel personally celebrated, not marketed to.

quotes.topic_title: External hype and delight: FigJam birthday launch
quotes.text: And I think that something that's quite interesting about hype and getting your users to feel strongly about your product is that every product has their own brand of delight or excitement or energy.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A mental model for tailoring launches: hype mechanics should match the product’s unique “energy,” not a one-size-fits-all playbook.

quotes.topic_title: Staying close to users: users, non-users, and sales calls
quotes.text: But I think that constantly immersing yourself in those circles where your users are is really important.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A practical operating principle: spend time where your users naturally are to keep your intuition grounded in reality.

quotes.topic_title: Staying close to users: users, non-users, and sales calls
quotes.text: And so something that I find incredibly useful is to not just ask users of your product what they think about your product, but to ask non-users about your product, why they're not using your product.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A repeatable research tactic: prioritize non-users to uncover adoption blockers you won’t hear from current customers.

quotes.topic_title: Staying close to users: users, non-users, and sales calls
quotes.text: And actually I think that those are the most insightful conversations because I think that having a product shine and having a product do well and have great adoption isn't just about the product being great. It's also about the marketing and the perceptions that surround the product and potentially the hype that surrounds that, right?
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A contrarian reminder that adoption is often constrained by perception and positioning, not just product quality.

quotes.topic_title: Staying close to users: users, non-users, and sales calls
quotes.text: And then that led to a series of product insights that led us to invest in a set of features that would make it much easier for a non-designer to get started out on the canvas.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: A concrete example of turning non-user feedback into roadmap investment focused on onboarding and first-use success.

quotes.topic_title: Staying close to users: users, non-users, and sales calls
quotes.text: And basically, just being on sales calls because you want to be in a situation where the customer pain points on sales calls are cross pollinating into the product roadmap, and you also want to ensure that your sales team has visibility into what might be coming and are constantly informing that.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: An operational method for larger companies: use sales calls as a structured input loop between customer pain and product planning.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing insights (partial, transcript cut off)
quotes.text: I sort of set up a recurring cadence with the folks in our sales team in order to understand like, "Okay, what are you guys hearing?"
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete operating rhythm for systematically capturing frontline customer insights via sales.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing insights (partial, transcript cut off)
quotes.text: And then I would share what was coming, and then I would use their input as signal as to what should be prioritized or deprioritized on the roadmap.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Describes a practical decision-making loop: translate sales feedback into prioritization signals for the roadmap.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing insights (partial, transcript cut off)
quotes.text: And they would use my signal to understand what were the various use cases that they could be pushing with the customers.
quotes.speaker: Mihika Kapoor
quotes.context: Shows a two-way alignment mechanism where product shares direction back to sales to shape customer messaging and use-case discovery.
